turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Where's where I asked him about being scared?  You should work on your speech.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: No.  It makes me nervous to think about it.  Let's do this.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: He must have been great-looking, right?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Why do you say that?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Because nobody invites a bad- looking idiot to their bedroom.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Okay.  Let's do me.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Okay.  I feel like I'm slipping but do people who are actually slipping feel that way or is it always the really good people who are moving up who invariably think they're slipping because their standards are so high?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: This conversation is not worthy of you.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: I'd give anything if that were true.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Good night.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Wouldn't this be a great world if insecurity and desperation made us more attractive?  If needy were a turn-on?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Call if you get weird.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: They didn't hire Peter Stiller from the <u>Times</u> and he had a great audition tape.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: You want to start going over who they could have gotten?  They can't take on people like this for network news.  For God's sake.  What's going on?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Nine seconds.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Eleven and a half.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Oh, God.  Back it, Bobbie -- Bobbie?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: I didn't sleep.  They're giving me less and less air time.  They don't think I'm at all anchor material.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: If we don't get to their camp soon, we won't be able to tape the supplies coming in.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Last time Paul was sick they gave Connie the weekend news instead of me.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: You spend too much time -- much too much worrying about that crap...  Oh good.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Okay.  Great line at the end.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Did you shoot their boots?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: We can cut back at the end.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: To the pan of the supplies boxes --

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Can you believe it?  I just risked my life for a network that tests my face with focus groups.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: I write for you sometimes.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Not because you have to.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: I'll tell you later -- where you going to watch from?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Watch? --

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: I'll come by your place, right after...drink, take pills... Love you.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: I think the pilot that shot down the Libyan in 1981 is stationed right here.  Maybe you could get him -- and maybe Tom should say that our F-14 is one of the hardest planes to fly. They're nicknamed 'Tomcats'.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Thanks.  The F-14 is one of the most difficult planes to master.  Oh, you call them 'Tomcats' and in the 70's the first crop had a number of crashes.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Me again.  Hi.  Listen Gaddafi doesn't foam at the mouth or anything.  When you speak to him he's not at all nuts. He seems like a leader -- very impressive, self-control...that's what's so strange.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Right and we have the '81 pilot on the way in -- Nobody else will have him.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: You're welcome.  Sow how does it feel to...I know you gotta go -- Me too.  We're very busy here.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Well, whatever you think.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: I figured out exactly why it is I'm so hung up on getting a chance at weekend anchor...It's because if I do that well, they'll pay me more, treat me great and my life will be better.  That's why.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Sounds like you may be on to something.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Which means I'm at their mercy and who wants that?...I'm not going to tell you where this thought led me... Anyway, well, why not  tell you? -- it's a happy thing.  In the middle of all this I start to think about something that does nothing but make me feel good and makes immediate sense and that's you ...And I'll stop here but, Jane, I'd give anything if you were two people so I could call up the one who's my friend and tell her about the one I'm in I...I don't think I should go any further.  Come on -- I'll walk you to the corner.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: You know you've had a strange day... I'd sleep on all these things you've been thinking.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Absolutely...You go have a good time... You have some place to go?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Jesus, Jane.  How long have you been here?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: A long time.  I was restless. Will you crack my neck?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Aaah --  -- ello.  You sure they said the management meeting?  They want me to be at the management meeting.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: They're not that dumb, after all.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Tom...why don't I meet you there? I've got some last minute stuff I've got to take care of...Hey, how did you resolve your dilemma -- did you rent the tux or buy it...I knew it. How much?  Wow...Okay...See you there...

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: I didn't know you were going with him.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Did you bring your grey suit?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Yes...I was thinking that way too... Which tie?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: I read about it -- that's how you can make sure you don't put on too much perfume...

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Could you at least pretend that this is an awkward situation for you -- me showing up while you're getting ready for a date.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: It's not a date.  It's co-workers going to a professional conclave.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Because this is important -- so don't just be polite.  I'd really like to look...what's the word I'm looking for?...

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: As good as humanly possible.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Well, the line of the jacket -- No really....just very nice...just right. I wish I could be there.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Me too...Hey...if it gets dull a little before 11:00, drop by the studio.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: I'm not sure I'll be able to...I...

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: <u>If</u>...if not, I'll have the tape...I'll wait for you at my apartment.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Okay, great -- good luck.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Thanks, Jane.  Have a good time tonight.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: You too.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: How'd it go?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: You didn't see it or speak to anybody?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Then it went well.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Did it really go well?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Define your terms.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Do you feel good about it?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Do others feel that you did well?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Then what was good about it?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: I lost six pounds...

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Aaron, will you tell me?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: It was great...writing my little first rate copy, sitting on my jacket, punching my one thought. But I had this historic attack of flop sweat so they'll never let me another again.  Oh, I lost one of your shoulder pads -- how was your evening anyway?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: What do you mean, flop sweat? -- you're making too much out of it...I'll bet you were the only one aware of it...

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: People phoned in.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Stop kidding.  I want to know what happened.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: I'm not kidding.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: There were complaining phone calls because you were sweating?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: No, nice ones worried that I was having a heart attack.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: If all that happened, how come you're so chipper?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: I don't know.  At a certain point it was so off the chart bad -- it got funny.  My central nervous system was telling me something. Jane -- sweat running down my face -- makeup falling into my eyes -- people turning this fusillade of blow dryers on me -- all so I could read introductions to other people who were covering stories which is what I like to do anyway.  And I'm chipper because you finally showed up.  I thought I'd cook for us. Tequila and eggs sound good?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: I have to be somewhere.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: I told what's his name -- Tom -- that I'd meet him.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Call him -- I mean it can wait, right?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: I don't know.  I may be in love with him.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Don't go.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: This is important to me.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Yeah.  Well...I think it is important for you too.  Sit down.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Let me think a second.  It's tough.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Aaach...Jane...  Let's take the part that has nothing to do with me.  Let's let me be your most trusted friend, the one that gets to say awful things to you.  You know?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Yes, I guess.  Yes.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: You can't end up with Tom because it goes totally against everything you're about.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Yeah -- being a basket case.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: I know you care about him.  I've never seen you like this about anyone, so please don't take it wrong when I tell you that I believe that Tom, while a very nice guy, is the Devil.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: This isn't friendship.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: What do you think the Devil is going to look like if he's around?  Nobody is going to be taken in if he has a long, red, pointy tail.  No.  I'm semi-serious here.  He will look attractive and he will be nice and helpful and he will get a job where he influences a great God-fearing nation and he will never do an evil thing...he will just bit by little bit lower standards where they are important. Just coax along flash over substance... Just a tiny bit.  And he will talk about all of us really being salesmen.  And he'll get all the great women.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: I think you're the Devil.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: No.  You know that I'm not.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Because we have the kind of relationship where if I were the Devil, you'd be the only one I told.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: You were quick enough to get Tom's help when...

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Yes, yes.  I know.  Right.  And if it had gone well for me tonight, maybe I'd be keeping quiet about all this...I grant you everything but give me this...he does personify everything you've been fighting against...And I'm in love with you.  How do you like that? -- I buried the lead.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: I've got to not say that aloud; it takes too much out of me.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Sit down, stop.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Don't say anything about anything.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Hi.  Will I ever sing again?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Bastard, sneak, quitter.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Speaking.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: I just found out.  You didn't say anything to me?  You just resign? Will you meet me now? -- No, now! I'm going away tomorrow.  Please.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Why not try it for a few weeks?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Stop.  Ernie thought I was good too -- he couldn't help.  My agent has a hot prospect -- the number two station in Portland.  The general manager says he wants to be every bit as good as the networks.  Personally, I think he should aim higher.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Tell me the God's honest truth -- are you leaving because of me? Because if you are...

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Ernie told this story.  How he used to write obits and when the people in town called him up with death notices, he cried.  He was till that way when they promoted him out of obits.  He says you're lucky if you can get out while you could still cry.  I should have quit this place  three years ago.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: You're just trying to say all great stuff so I'll feel even worse that you're not around.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Let's go...

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: I just want to sit here longer, I mean the feeling is powerful -- why's that?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Maybe the best part of your life is over and you don't want to get up and start the bad part.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: You are now required to sit here with me.  Come on...be smart for a second -- what do you think will happen to us?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Okay, that's very easy.  Five, six years from now I'll be in town to collect an award representing the surge in foreign coverage by local stations.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: I'll be walking with my wife and two children -- we'll bump into you on the street, my youngest son will say something and I'll tell him...  ...it's not nice to make fun of single, fat ladies.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: You won't be able to stay mad at me, right?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: I hope so...  No.  I'm not really mad.  I'll miss you, we'll talk, we'll always be friends...we'll get hot for each other every few years at dinner and never act on it, okay?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: I think so...They've been talking to me about being Tom's Managing Editor.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: I'm going to take it.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: So who's the guy?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Well, we met about three months ago. He works at the surgeon general office. He loves boating.  So, he's been getting me into water skiing.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: I like it!  So, doll, what about you lately?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Well -- my wife got this new job...

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Ready.

turns.speaker: CAMERAMAN
turns.text: Your hair's a little funny.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: It's an ethnic curl, I can't do anything about it.

turns.speaker: CAMERAMAN
turns.text: In front of a little -- it's a bit... You want a mirror?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: No -- Don't worry about it.  Let's do this.

turns.speaker: CAMERAMAN
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: In other times, for other purposes, there might be a band and bunting here at the bus depot for J.D. Singer's return from war.  He...

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Oh, you mean use him...That's nice.  Okay.

turns.speaker: CAMERAMAN
turns.text: I'll put him in the low corner of the frame -- good.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: In other times, with other purposes, there might be a band and bunting here at the bus depot for J.D. Singer's return from war.  Last week he was decorated by a president for heroism in a war.  But it was the civil war -- in Angola -- and he was in it for the money.

turns.speaker: ERNIE
turns.text: I saw the smile -- good piece.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: I'm gonna go look at it again.

turns.speaker: ERNIE
turns.text: I had the strangest thing happen yesterday.  Anne and I have been married what? -- Thirty-six years... Everything fine -- two days after the promotion came through, I was checking myself in the mirror and she was making a face at me behind my back. So yesterday I looked in the mirror and she was doing it again.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: You didn't say anything to her?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: That's it.  I resign as of now.

turns.speaker: ERNIE
turns.text: Stop it.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: I'll tell you what.  I'll stay if Tom knows how to spell Gaddafi.

turns.speaker: ERNIE
turns.text: Oh, I was just writing you a note. What do you say we take a walk?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Outside?

turns.speaker: ERNIE
turns.text: Yeah --

turns.speaker: ERNIE
turns.text: I don't know if we have any younger man more respected in our operation than you.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Just tell me what's really going on.  I think we know each other well enough for me to expect that.

turns.speaker: ERNIE
turns.text: We know each other well enough for me to care how I put something to you which could wipe you out. So I will phrase things the way I think they should be phrased.  All right?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Wipe me out?

turns.speaker: ERNIE
turns.text: Anyway.  I want you to think of this as...

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Just blunt talk, okay?  I'd really appreciate bluntness.

turns.speaker: ERNIE
turns.text: Upper management thinks you're dull.

turns.speaker: ERNIE
turns.text: Aaron, I've never seen them like this -- I think Paul's nervous about his own job and for some reason he thinks you only appeal to...

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Wait.  Bullshit me a little...I'm beginning to appreciate it.

turns.speaker: ERNIE
turns.text: I'm no suggesting the worst will happen...but someone with your brilliance gets nibbles about other jobs and maybe, the next time that happens, down the road -- you should look into it.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Ah, damn -- the fucking jerks -- My, God.  They want to fire me.

turns.speaker: ERNIE
turns.text: All I know is that they've got to fire a large number of people... and they're not going by seniority. There's a recklessness in the air. They...

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Do one thing to me?  Get me one shot at anchoring the Weekend News -- they've never seen me do it.  I think it could turn them around.

turns.speaker: ERNIE
turns.text: I could do it this Saturday -- everyone wants off for the Correspondents' Dinner.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Do it then.

turns.speaker: ERNIE
turns.text: Please prepare carefully.  This couldn't come at a better time.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Prepare what?  You have Saturday's news handy?

turns.speaker: ERNIE
turns.text: It's been a while since you read the news -- I'll have somebody work with you.  Just on superficial performance things.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Okay.  I think I'd better be alone for a while.

turns.speaker: ERNIE
turns.text: I understand.  I'll go with you.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: ERNIE
turns.text: It's what he did.  I'm proud of him.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: They told me they'd keep me because they could plug me into any story and my salary was in line.

turns.speaker: ERNIE
turns.text: The cost-efficient reporter.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: So I quit.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Just a few questions?

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: We came from Washington.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Move away from me.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: How long has it been since you've been home.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Fuck.  Fuck.  Fuck.  Fuckes.  Snot... Fuckee.  You want to use that?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: It depends on how big a news day it is.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: All this business of war -- do you get scared?

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Uh-uh.  I'm a little freaked right now about seeing my father though.

turns.speaker: BLAIR
turns.text: Okay.  I just wanted you to know.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: What is she shooting?

turns.speaker: BLAIR
turns.text: Norman Rockwell's 'Homecoming.'

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Oh, that's nice...  We'll need some new lines.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Norman Rockwell's enduring portrait of a <u>Homecoming</u>  The return of a fighting man has always been one of the more moving ceremonies of war... Tearful women, proud men, excited children.  But J.D. Singer was right -- his homecoming was no big deal.

turns.speaker: BLAIR
turns.text: We have a minute and a half.  It's my responsibility to tell them we won't be ready.

turns.speaker: BLAIR
turns.text: I was a little nervous there for a minute.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Oh, come on -- tell us another.

turns.speaker: BLAIR
turns.text: Goodbye, Paul.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Take care, Paul.  It takes a certain kind of courage for you to say that in front of the President of the News Division.

turns.speaker: BLAIR
turns.text: You think anyone who's proud of the work we do is an ass kisser.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: No.  I think anyone who puckers their lips and presses it against his boss' buttocks and then smooches is an ass kisser.

turns.speaker: BLAIR
turns.text: My gosh, and for a while there, I was attracted to you.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Just when do you start, telling people?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Almost immediately.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I'd like to take everyone out after the show.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Bill...This is hard on all of us and it's no time for compliments. But I think it's extraordinary of you to come down here for this.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: If we're not here for each other during the tough time, we're not a news organization.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: This is a brutal layoff...And all because they couldn't program Wednesdays.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You can make it a little less brutal by knocking a million dollars or so off your salary.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Jane?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Well, darling, if it gets any better than that, I'm going to have to bring you up here to New York.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Thanks.  I just wish you'd kept the first twenty seconds.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: But thanks.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Well, the visual with the boots at the end was just perfect.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Aaron should be hearing this so I have an extra witness.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Well, you always want to give the credit away, do you?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: No, I don't.  He happens to deserve the credit.  He's right here.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I'll speak to you soon

turns.speaker: BLAIR
turns.text: You don't have time.  Not a chance.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: I'll be right down.  It's right tight.

turns.speaker: BLAIR
turns.text: I've got to tell Ernie...because there isn't enough time.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Yes, there is.

turns.speaker: BLAIR
turns.text: What did he say?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: I'll never tell.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Yeah, I know, I went back and forth on it.

turns.speaker: BLAIR
turns.text: I liked it.  He's not afraid to be human.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Tell George and Jessica to try and cover everything without Tom having to ask additional questions.

turns.speaker: BLAIR
turns.text: And Bobbie says...

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Did you hear what I just said -- do you have that?  Take a breath.

turns.speaker: BLAIR
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: BLAIR
turns.text: It's Aaron.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: BLAIR
turns.text: Do you know you're the second woman in network news history to produce?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: No, I'm not.  I'm the fourth. Joan Richmond.  Pauline Fredericks got that credit once on a U.N. special and there's Susan Zirinsky.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: What are you dressed up for?  Oh, that's right -- because the Evening News is here this week.

turns.speaker: BLAIR
turns.text: I spent a fortune on this.

turns.speaker: BLAIR
turns.text: They canned me.  Well, my brother will feel great -- now he's not the only screw-up.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: It's started.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Go back to 316, Bobbie.  The sound bite in the cab -- it starts, 'I don't know how I'll feel...'

turns.speaker: BOBBIE
turns.text: We could...

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Please, Bobbie, we're pushing.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Play back the last line...

turns.speaker: BOBBIE
turns.text: He said something about...

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Let me hear it!

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Okay, Bobbie, just a two-second dissolve to the Rockwell.

turns.speaker: BOBBIE
turns.text: Should I...

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Just a two-second dissolve.

turns.speaker: BOBBIE
turns.text: Do you want him all the way to the car?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: No stop where he's all besieged.

turns.speaker: BOBBIE
turns.text: Because...

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Right there, Bobbie.

turns.speaker: BOBBIE
turns.text: You know, I like Tom, because hi...

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Bobbie, please.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: They're not really going to call security are they?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: No, I don't think so.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: How do I get out of here?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Follow me.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: You talked me into it.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I've been doing some morning show stuff, but mostly radio -- that doesn't bother me.  I'm in no rush for anything.  It's just the snotty attitude, even if I have it coming, it's still...

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Bad manners.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Yes.  That's right.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: I know...I mean you didn't do anything special for me tonight.  You just had what I think are good manners, decency. And it really makes me want to be nice back and it has nothing to do with any homosexual thing.  Honestly.  Because I don't know if you've homosexual or not and -- you're not, are you?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: No...no.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: One's enough.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I really have to go.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Okay.  At least let me show my appreciation.  The Secretary of Labor is going to be indicted on Wednesday. For the graft thing he supposedly did before he was appointed.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Yes, it's true.  They're going to make it public Wednesday but isn't it a big deal for you to have it a day and a half early?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Yes.  How do you know?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: My roommate's very social -- somebody from Justice was over and...I always hear things before they happen.  Hey, and from now on, so do you.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: ...and the White House is hoping to keep a lid on it for a few days till they figure out what to do.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Thanks a lot, Buddy.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Oh, please.  So they were really impressed with you at work.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Not impressed exactly -- but a break in the clouds.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: I see the change in you -- I see it.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Forgive me, but it really is intoxicating being a news source.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Nobody else had it.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: I wish it were you giving the story.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: That's okay.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: What if we just don't tell them anything anymore unless they let you do the story?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: No.  Really...don't worry about it.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Okay.  And look, in the future I can call you when I have news for you. Don't feel you have to spend time with me just to get the information.  Well, that wasn't as hard to say as you thought, was it, Buddy?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: What do you mean?  You're one of the few people in this town I can talk to.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Hey, Buddy, don't do that anymore.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Is everything all right?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Yes.  You didn't have to come here. It's just that I'm going to anchor this special report on this Libyan thing...

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Anchor?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Yes, stop!  I wondered if you could find out anything about what's happening.  What's wrong?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: I broke up with my roommate -- He was really the magnet for everyone who knew anything.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Look, I can start up with him again if you really...

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: No.  I'm doing fine...Look.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Good.  He's on the world's longest ego trip, let him take it alone.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Hey, okay.  Look Buddy -- I've got to go to work.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: ...good-bye then.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I'll speak to you.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Well, who knows.  Just let m tell you what my favorite teacher ever, told me -- 'Don't be afraid to be wonderful.'

turns.speaker: WIFE
turns.text: Ernie, they're calling from work.

turns.speaker: ERNIE
turns.text: Tell me I'm on the way in.

turns.speaker: WIFE
turns.text: It's Paul.

turns.speaker: WIFE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ERNIE
turns.text: They fired me.

turns.speaker: WIFE
turns.text: How horrible.  We'll be fine.  You'll be fine.  Stay here with me -- we'll go for a drive, have some drinks, make happy plans.

turns.speaker: ERNIE
turns.text: No.  They're firing even more people than they said.  Some will want to talk.  It could help.

turns.speaker: WIFE
turns.text: I could use somebody to talk to on a day like this.  Sorry. Go ahead.

turns.speaker: ERNIE
turns.text: Bye, sweetie.

turns.speaker: WIFE
turns.text: Okay, sweetie.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: ...am starting to get jealous. I read in the newspapers about the Italian strike and riots in Milan.  I hope you weren't...

turns.speaker: FATHER
turns.text: Honey?...

turns.speaker: FATHER
turns.text: Jane -- For God's sake...  Look, it's time for you to go to sleep.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: I just have two more pen pals and then I'm done.

turns.speaker: FATHER
turns.text: You don't have to finish tonight.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Nooo.  This way the rotation stays the same.

turns.speaker: FATHER
turns.text: Finish quickly.  I don't want you getting obsessive about these things.  Good night.

turns.speaker: GERALD
turns.text: I don't know a recent Saturday I've sold more.  You didn't think I'd sell that health restaurant, did you?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: No.  Not even you.

turns.speaker: GERALD
turns.text: Why so glum?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: GERALD
turns.text: Go ahead.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: No, nothing.  I've got a problem, I guess.

turns.speaker: GERALD
turns.text: Were you bothering by those waitresses making a fuss?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: No.  But, honest.  What are you supposed to say when they keep talking about your looks?  I don't even know what they mean -- "Beat them off with a stick."

turns.speaker: GERALD
turns.text: You know, Tom, I feel a little proud when people comment on your looks.  Maybe you should feel that way.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Proud?  I'm just embarrassed that I like when they say those things.

turns.speaker: GERALD
turns.text: As long as that's your only problem you're...

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: It's not.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I got my report card.  Three Cs, two Ds and an incomplete.

turns.speaker: GERALD
turns.text: Oh my.  I see you studying so hard, Tom.  What do you think the problem is?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I'll just have to try harder.  I don't know.  I will.  I will.  I will.  I will.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Thanks, Dad, this talk helped.  Will you sign it, please?

turns.speaker: GERALD
turns.text: Would it help if I got you a tutor?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: That would be great.  It better help.  What can you do with yourself if all you do is look good?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Tom isn't ready for the job you're about to hand him.  Not near ready.  Not by the longest shot.  Aaron's spent six weeks in Tripoli, he's interviewed Gaddafi -- he reported on the Eight-one story.  I think he's essential to do the job we're capable of and I think it's my responsibility to tell you that.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Okay, that's your opinion.  I don't agree.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: It's not opinion.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You're just absolutely right and I'm absolutely wrong?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: It must be nice to always believe you know better.  To think you're always the smartest person in the room.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: No, it's awful.  Oh my, it's awful.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I had no idea she was this good.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Fill for a second.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I just wanted to tell you  how great you were.  My name's Tom Grunick.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Thank you.  They hated me.  I don't hate them.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Well, they say if you can reach even one person, it means something... And you did that.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Hi.  I was worried I was early.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I was a lot earlier.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I kept thinking what a great break it was for me to get to see you tonight.  More than a great break, maybe just what I needed...just when I needed it...Angel of mercy -- godsend...lifesaver...what?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: I like "godsend."

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I haven't been in news that long. I've just been looking for the right person to talk to.  I have about two thousand questions for you.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: If we could just eat first.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Totally understood.  Totally wrong of me to talk shop after the day you've had.  Totally sorry.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Nooo.  If I could just have a roll, I'd be okay.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Another thing I can't stand is ...when White House reporters bullshit with each other after a briefing and then one of them has a theory and the other quotes it in his story as "White House" sources say...

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: That actually goes on...

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Yes.  My room is down here -- I'm not tired.  Do you want to keep talking?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Yes, sure.
